awd_titl_txt: Broadening Participation in the Compound Semiconductor Week 2022
awd_abstract_narration:
The project provides partial support to students, new principal investigators (New Faces) and underrepresented minority (URM) researchers to participate in the conference Compound Semiconductor Week (CSW), being held from June 1 to June 3, 2022 in Ann Arbor, Michigan. The Compound Semiconductor Week brings together the international community of researchers.  It is one of the first international conferences to prioritize the in-person experience of the participants while providing a hybrid option during the pandemic. Promotion of research in compound semiconductors, an important genre of semiconductors, is poised to make a significant impact on basic collaborative research and workforce development in the field of semiconductors. The CSW 2022 is expected to host 250 participants with about half of them being students.  The technical program with 12 subtopics is designed to achieve a purposeful balance and inclusiveness considering researcher’s gender, origin, ethnicity, seniority and research topics. In addition, to debuting new independent principal investigators to the research community, the CSW 2022 curated a program for the New Faces in Compound Semiconductors, providing a critical experience for the research community to transition through the pandemic period.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor

por.por_cntn:
This project provided funds to support students, new principal investigators (new faces), and underrepresented minority (URM) researchers' participation in Compound Semiconductor Week (CSW), which was held from June 1 to June 3, 2022, in Ann Arbor, Michigan. Compound Semiconductor Week is one of the most prestigious forums for bringing together the international community of researchers. It is also one of the first international conferences to prioritize the in-person experience of the participants while providing a hybrid option during this trying time.  The conference website https://csw2022.engin.umich.edu recorded the activities. There were 111 student attendees among 248 total participants.  

 

Intellectual Merit:

 

The conference gathered a representative group of highly active researchers in the compound semiconductor field. They shared their most up-to-date findings in scientific research activities. Researchers presented and discussed their research findings in the following 12 topical areas:

 

1. Materials and Characterization

1.1 Narrow bandgap materials

1.2 Nanostructures

1.3 Novel materials and characterization

1.4 Wide and ultra-wide bandgap materials

 

2. Devices and Technologies

2.1 High-frequency devices

2.2 Power electronics

2.3 Semiconductor lasers and LEDs

2.4 Optoelectronics and Integrated Photonics

 

3. Physics and Emerging Devices

3.1 Semiconductor physics

3.2 Organic semiconductors and flexible electronics

3.3 Other novel device concepts including ferroelectrics, spintronics etc.

3.4 Quantum electronic and photonic devices

 

Broader Impact:

The conference's subject is highly focused on compound semiconductor materials, from theory to experiments and materials to applications. The diverse and comprehensive coverage of the conference is of primary importance in the formation of scientists to be leaders in the new millennium. The intrinsic educational value of the conference has exposed the student participants to cutting-edge research layered materials.  Equally importantly, students and other junior researchers met their role models in person.  

 

To highlight our effort to broaden participation in CSW, we show the numbers of CSW 2022 below.  

 

  • 2 conferences (ISCS + IPRM = Compound Semiconductor Week)
  • 9 New Faces debuted
  • 2 short courses
    • Ferroelectric materials and devices
    • Compound semiconductors: from epi to state-of-the-art devices (by 1 senior female researcher)
  • 2 rump session
    • Power electronics
    • From mobile displays to virtual reality: Micro LED vs OLED
  • 4 plenary talks (including 1 mid-career female researcher)
  • 3 tracks:
    • Materials and characterization
    • Devices and technologies
    • Physics and emerging devices
  • 5 awards:
    • Welker Award
    • ISCS Quantum Device Award
    • ISCS Young Scientist Award
    • IPRM Award
    • CSW Best Student Paper Award
  • 33 invited talks
  • 191 contributed papers
  • 248 attendees with 111 students
  • >10,000 emails

 


Last Modified: 03/12/2024
Modified by: Pei-Cheng Ku
